The water was a lie. It promised purity, a clean, chlorinated void where the city and its filth couldn't follow. For Anouk Reiss, the long, sapphire lane of the Piscine Pontoise was a sanctuary, a place of rhythmic, meditative violence against the unyielding medium. Stroke, kick, breathe. The world reduced to muscle burn and the muffled, percussive thump of her own heart. She was not DI Reiss in here. She was a body in motion, a swimmer, carving a path through the quiet blue. The tiled cross at the end of the lane approached, blurred, and then sharpened. She executed a perfect tumble turn, a fluid coil and release that sent a silent shockwave through the water. For a moment, suspended upside down, the submerged lights of the old pool looked like distant, drowned stars. This was peace. The only peace she ever really knew.

Stroke, kick, breathe. The mantra that had taken her from the junior leagues in Paris to the edge of national recognition, before the realities of a different life, a different calling, had pulled her from the water and onto the blood-spattered pavement. But she never truly left. Every morning before the sun bothered to climb over the zinc-and-slate rooftops, she was here. Washing the day before away. Or trying to. Today’s residue was particularly foul. A domestic dispute in the 15th that had ended with a porcelain figurine and a caved-in skull. The killer had been wearing his wife’s floral apron. Reiss could still smell the coppery tang of blood mixed with the cloying scent of cheap perfume. The water was supposed to wash that away. But the memory was greasy. It clung.

A frantic waving from the side of the pool broke her rhythm. It was Jean-Pierre, the young lifeguard, his face pale and tight. He was pointing at his own ear, then at the front desk. The phone. A knot of ice formed in Reiss’s gut, instantly negating the warmth generated by the exercise. Calls to the pool were never good. They meant the world had refused to wait. She swam to the edge, her movements suddenly graceless, urgent. Pulling herself out, water sluicing from her lean, powerful frame, she didn't bother with a towel. The chill on her skin was a prelude.

“Inspector?” Jean-Pierre offered the cordless phone like it was a venomous snake. “It’s Inspector Dubois. He said it’s… important.”

Reiss took it, the cold plastic a shock against her wet hand. “Reiss.”

“Anouk. Sorry to pull you out of the soup.” Her partner’s voice was gravelly, scraped raw by a lifetime of Gauloises and late nights. “But you need to see this.”

“Another domestic?” she asked, her own voice flat.

A pause. A long, weary sigh crackled down the line. “No. Not even close. This is… something else. Something new. Meet me at Lycée Charlemagne. In the Marais.”

“A school?” The ice in her stomach spread to her limbs. Schools were supposed to be like her pool. Sanctuaries. “What’s the situation?”

“The situation,” Dubois rasped, and she could hear the grimace in his voice, “is that a teacher is dead. And the first responders are calling the weapon a ‘splurge-gun’. You’re going to want your strongest stomach for this one. And Anouk? Hurry.”

The line went dead. Splurge-gun. The word was ugly, cartoonish, and utterly terrifying. It didn't belong in the vocabulary of a Parisian homicide detective. Reiss stood dripping on the cold tiles, the lie of the water evaporating around her, leaving her exposed and cold. The city had found her again.

The drive across Paris was a smear of grey rain and blurred neon. Dubois sat hunched in the passenger seat of her unassuming Peugeot, the glow of his phone illuminating the deep-set lines of exhaustion on his face. He’d been at the scene for an hour already. He smelled of wet wool and the acidic scent of pure dread.

“The victim is Karim Al-Jamil,” Dubois said, not looking up from his screen. “History teacher. Forty-two. Married, two kids. By all accounts, a saint. The kind of teacher kids actually like. Ran the debate club, coached the girls’ football team.”

“And the weapon?” Reiss kept her eyes on the road, the windscreen wipers beating a frantic, hypnotic rhythm.

Dubois finally looked over, his eyes dark and troubled. “You’ll see. Forensics is baffled. It’s not a firearm. No casing, no entry wound in the traditional sense. It’s… high pressure. Catastrophically high pressure. The scene is… it’s like an abattoir. But an abstract one. The ME said it looks like the man was turned into a piece of modern art. His words.”

Reiss’s hands tightened on the wheel. She hated it when they got poetic. It meant the reality was too grotesque for plain language. “Motive? Robbery?”

“Nothing was taken. Wallet, watch, phone, all there. He was working late, grading papers in his classroom. Alone.” Dubois swiped through his phone again. “This is the part that gets weird. Or weirder.”

The Lycée Charlemagne loomed ahead, a grand old fortress of learning, its stone façade streaked with rain and bathed in the lurid, strobing colours of police lights. The incongruity was sickening. Reiss parked behind a row of emergency vehicles, the chatter of radios cutting through the steady hiss of the downpour. A perimeter had been established, a few students and residents held back by uniformed officers, their faces a mixture of curiosity and horror.

“The classroom is on the second floor,” Dubois grunted, pulling the collar of his coat up. “The principal found him. He’s in the nurse’s office, sedated. Useless.”

They didn't need the principal. The scene told its own story. The hallway was unnaturally quiet, the usual scent of chalk dust and teenage anxiety replaced with the sharp, metallic odour of blood and disinfectant. A forensics officer in a white paper suit nodded at them as they ducked under the tape. “Inspectors. Be prepared.”

The classroom was a tableau of interrupted academia. Posters of the French Revolution and Enlightenment philosophers lined the walls. A stack of neatly corrected essays sat on the edge of the desk, the top one titled ‘Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité: An Ideal or a Reality?’. And in the centre of the room, the source of the smell, the epicentre of the horror. Karim Al-Jamil, or what was left of him, was slumped in his chair. Dubois hadn't been exaggerating. There was no single point of impact. His entire torso was a mangled, shredded ruin of flesh and fabric, blasted outward against the blackboard behind him. The chalk dust had mixed with the spray, creating a grotesque, pastel-coloured fresco of annihilation. ‘Splurge-gun’ was a horrifyingly accurate descriptor. It looked as though he had been inflated and then simply… burst.

Reiss felt the bile rise in her throat. She swallowed it down, her swimmer’s discipline kicking in. Detach. Observe. The desk was untouched, save for the spray. The papers were pristine. The victim’s hands were resting in his lap, almost peaceful, a bizarre counterpoint to the devastation of his body. She walked the perimeter of the room, her eyes scanning every detail. The open window. The faint scuff marks near the door. The absolute lack of any struggle.

“He was taken by surprise,” she murmured, her voice a low hum. “Sat at his desk, and then… this.”

“From the doorway, we think,” Dubois said, pointing with his pen. “Maximum effective range seems to be about three meters. Whatever it is, it’s not a long-distance weapon.”

Reiss knelt, her eyes level with the blasted chair. She saw it then. Tucked just under the victim’s shoe, a small, laminated card. She motioned to a forensics tech. “Bag that. Carefully.”

The tech used a pair of tweezers to lift the card. It was a simple business card, but on its reverse was a crudely printed symbol: a stylized, broken cross inside a circle. And beneath it, a single, typed word.

*Remplacé.*

Replaced.

“What the hell does that mean?” Dubois muttered, peering over her shoulder.

Reiss stood up, a cold certainty beginning to dawn. It felt different from the sordid, pathetic motives she usually dealt with. This wasn't passion or greed. It was ideology. It was a statement. “It means this isn’t over,” she said, her voice barely a whisper. “This is the opening line.”

Her phone buzzed. It was a call from the central dispatch. Her blood ran cold. It was too soon for another body.

“DI Reiss,” she answered, her tone clipped.

“Inspector,” the dispatcher’s voice was strained, high-pitched. “We have… another situation. It’s connected to your scene at the Lycée.”

“How?” Dubois asked, moving closer to the phone.

“A woman. Élise Moreau. In the 4th arrondissement. She’s a teacher at Lycée Charlemagne. A friend of the victim. She called police half an hour ago, hysterical. Said a courier had just delivered a package. Said it was from… from Karim Al-Jamil.”

Reiss felt the floor drop out from under her. The package. The friend. The post. This was the other part of the ritual.

“She wouldn't open the door for the first patrol car,” the dispatcher continued, his voice cracking. “They had to break it down. Inspector… the package contained a human head.”

Dubois swore, a long, heartfelt string of profanities that was almost a prayer. Reiss felt nothing. Just the vast, cold emptiness of the deep end of the pool. The lie of the water. This killer wasn’t just murdering people. They were weaponizing grief, turning friendship into a vessel for horror. They were posting the shrapnel of their hatred directly into the hearts of the people left behind. And that symbol, that word… *Remplacé*. This was a crusade. A declaration of war against people like Karim Al-Jamil. People this monster, this Talia, believed were replacing the ‘true’ France. Reiss looked at the ruin in the chair, then at the blackboard where the phrase ‘Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité’ was still faintly visible beneath the spray of blood and tissue. This wasn't just murder. It was a message, written in the most obscene ink imaginable, and it was addressed to the entire world. And she, DI Anouk Reiss, was the one who had to read it.The drive to the 4th was a descent into a deeper circle of hell. The rain had intensified, lashing against the windscreen as if trying to wash the city clean, a futile effort. Dubois was silent now, the phone call having stripped away his gallows humour, leaving only a grim, stony resolve. Reiss felt a strange, hyper-aware calm settle over her. The shock was a physical thing, a carapace of ice forming over her nerves. It was the only way to function. The pool had taught her to hold her breath; the job had taught her to hold her soul, to keep it from breaking the surface and drowning in the filth. They were no longer just chasing a killer. They were pursuing a phantom who could be in two places at once, whose cruelty was a form of architecture, building monuments of despair.

Élise Moreau’s apartment was on the third floor of a handsome Haussmannian building on the Rue de Rivoli, its wrought-iron balconies overlooking a street of chic boutiques and bustling cafes. The dissonance was nauseating. Inside, the air was thick with a new kind of silence, the sound of a life that has been irrevocably shattered. A medic was leading a woman, presumably Moreau, towards a waiting ambulance. She was wrapped in a shock blanket, her face a blank mask of incomprehension, her eyes fixed on something in the middle distance that no one else could see. She didn't make a sound. The loudest screams are often the ones you cannot hear.

Reiss and Dubois entered the living room. It was a scholar’s haven, books piled on every surface, prints of classical art on the walls, a half-finished cup of tea growing cold on a small table. It smelled of old paper, lemon, and fear. And in the centre of the polished herringbone floor sat a simple cardboard courier box. It had been torn open, the flaps splayed like a grotesque flower. The forensics team had already cordoned it off, but the violation was permanent. It was an object of pure malevolence, an invader from a nightmare dimension dropped into the heart of a peaceful life. Reiss didn't need to look inside. The presence of it was enough. The sight of the cheerful, generic courier logo on the side of the box, smeared with the fingerprints of the hysterical recipient, was more obscene than the contents it had held.

“The delivery was made forty-five minutes ago. A man in a generic courier uniform. We’re pulling traffic camera footage, but my guess is he’ll be a ghost,” a junior detective reported, his own face pale. “The sender’s address was listed as Lycée Charlemagne. The sender’s name…” he trailed off, glancing at the manifest in his hand. “Karim Al-Jamil.”

Dubois let out a breath that was half-curse, half-sob. “He weaponized his ghost. He sent a dead man to deliver a nightmare to his best friend.” He looked at Reiss, his eyes pleading for an explanation that didn't exist. “What kind of monster does this? What kind of mind even conceives of it?”

Reiss’s gaze was fixed on the delivery label. The cold, disciplined part of her brain was working, connecting the pieces, ignoring the screaming protest from the rest of her humanity. The timing. The logistics. This wasn't a crime of passion. It was an operation. It required planning, resources, and a complete absence of anything resembling a soul. This killer had a list. They had a schedule.

A forensics officer, a man Reiss had known for a decade, approached them. His usual morbid cheerfulness was gone. “Anouk. The head… it’s a male, Caucasian, probably in his fifties. We’ve already run a preliminary facial recognition scan against the national database. We have a hit.” He took a deep breath. “His name is Jean-Luc Tissot. He was reported missing by his wife two days ago.”

“What was his profession?” Reiss asked, the icy carapace inside her growing thicker, colder.

The officer looked down at his tablet. “He was a city planner. Head of the Urban Renewal project for the 19th arrondissement.”

*Remplacé*. Replaced. The word echoed in the sudden, ringing silence of Reiss’s mind. A history teacher of Algerian descent, a symbol of the new France. A city planner, responsible for literally changing the face of the city, for renewing, for… replacing the old. The logic was perverse, insane, but it was there. It was a pattern. The killer wasn’t just targeting people; they were targeting ideas embodied by people. They were editing reality with a high-pressure hose and a butcher’s knife.

“There will be another card,” Reiss said, her voice a dead monotone. She walked over to the forensics team working on the body part, now respectfully covered. “Check the packaging. Check the box. It will be there.”

It took them less than a minute. Tucked into the bottom of the cardboard box, beneath the blood-soaked packing material, was another laminated card. The same as the first. The broken cross inside a circle. And beneath it, the same chilling, single word.

*Remplacé.*

Reiss stared at the identical cards in the evidence bags—one from a classroom, one from a box that held a human head. It wasn’t just a signature. It was a receipt. A proof of purchase for a life taken. She looked from the card to the stunned faces of the officers around her, to the empty space where Élise Moreau had stood. This killer didn't just leave a body. They created a blast radius of trauma, sending shrapnel into the lives of everyone connected to the victim. Karim Al-Jamil was the explosion. Élise Moreau was the collateral damage. And Jean-Luc Tissot… he was the ammunition for the next round. The cold certainty hit her like a physical blow. This wasn't two murders. It was a single, continuous, horrifying process. The headquarters of the Brigade Criminelle at 36, quai des Orfèvres was a humming hive of controlled panic. What had begun as a whisper from a lifeguard’s phone at dawn had, by noon, become a roar that consumed every resource the city’s most elite detective unit could command. The rain continued its assault on the historic building’s windows, but inside, the storm was one of data. Phones rang with a shrill, incessant urgency, uniformed officers ferried files and coffee, and the air grew thick with the scents of wet coats, ozone from the servers, and a city-wide anxiety that had seeped through the stone walls. In the media, they were already being given names: the Splurge-Gun Killer, the Blackboard Butcher. But here, in the main briefing room, they were simply called *Remplacé*.

Reiss and Dubois stood before a vast digital whiteboard, its surface a chaotic mosaic of horror. The faces of Karim Al-Jamil and Jean-Luc Tissot stared out, frozen in time from their ID photos, vibrant and unaware. Next to them were crime scene photos—the abstract horror of the classroom, the stark violation of the courier box. In the centre, glowing like a toxic sigil, was the crudely drawn symbol of the broken cross in its circle. The two laminated cards were displayed side-by-side, their single, chilling word repeated like a drumbeat. Every detective in the room, from the most jaded veteran to the greenest rookie, looked at the board with the same mixture of revulsion and grim focus. This was not a crime they had ever seen before. It felt like a tear in the fabric of their reality.

The Prefect of Police himself had made an appearance, a sleek, political animal in a tailored suit who spoke of containing public fear and managing the media narrative. He used words like ‘unprecedented’ and ‘barbaric’, but his eyes betrayed a more primal fear: that of a man who felt the ground shifting beneath his feet. He wanted answers, but more than that, he wanted control. He looked at Reiss, his gaze lingering, knowing her reputation for navigating the darkest currents of the human psyche. "Inspector Reiss," he had said, his voice a low command. "Find this animal. Before he writes his next line." The Prefect’s visit had left a film of political desperation over everything, another layer of grime the water in the pool could never wash away.

A young tech analyst, barely old enough to shave, stood by the board, trying to lend scientific order to the madness. “The term ‘Remplacé’ is, as you’d expect, a direct reference to the ‘Grand Remplacement’,” he explained, his voice tight. “The conspiracy theory popular in far-right circles that native French populations are being deliberately replaced by non-European immigrants. It’s the cornerstone of dozens of extremist ideologies. The symbol, however… that’s new. We’ve run it through every database—Interpol, Europol, our own domestic intelligence archives. It doesn’t match any known group, neo-Nazi, nationalist, or otherwise. It’s bespoke. Our killer has his own logo.”

Reiss listened, her mind a still, deep pool of concentration. While others saw a political theory, she saw the architecture of a psychosis. It wasn't about politics, not really. It was about a narcissistic rage so profound it needed to invent an entire cosmology to justify its own violence. The killer wasn’t a soldier in a war; they were the god of their own filthy religion, and these murders were their acts of creation. Internally, she had already given the killer a name. Talia. It was the name of a cruel ice-queen from a storybook she’d read as a child, a sorceress who delighted in turning living things into frozen, grotesque statues. It was better than the sterile ‘subject’ or ‘perpetrator’. It gave the evil a shape, a thing she could hunt, rather than just an idea she had to endure.

“We have a preliminary analysis of the… residue… from the Al-Jamil scene,” a forensics liaison announced, her face grim. The room fell silent. “It’s not a projectile weapon. There was no explosive. The ME’s report confirms the victim’s body was subjected to a catastrophic hydraulic overpressure event. We found trace elements of polyalkylene glycol and phosphate esters in the blast pattern. It’s a specialized, high-performance hydraulic fluid. The kind used in heavy industrial and demolition machinery—high-pressure cutters, rams, that sort of thing. The weapon is almost certainly a custom-built device, a hydraulic cannon. It’s not something you buy. It’s something you build, if you have the expertise.”

Dubois let out a low whistle, rubbing the grey stubble on his jaw. “So, we are looking for a disgruntled engineer? A demolition expert with a god complex and a subscription to a racist newsletter? Someone with access to a workshop and the materials to build this… this monstrosity?” It was a practical, solid line of inquiry, a piece of firm ground in a swamp of insanity. But Reiss was already a step beyond the practical. She was looking at the board, at the victims, at the weapon’s composition, and she was seeing the poetry of it. The terrible, sickening poetry.

“It’s not just the tool he used,” she said, her voice quiet but carrying across the room. “It’s part of the message. Jean-Luc Tissot was a city planner. He headed an Urban Renewal project. He literally tore down the old to make way for the new. To… replace it.” She let the word hang in the air. “Talia uses the fluid of demolition to demolish a man who taught a new history of France. The symbolism is the point. The weapon, the victim, the word—it’s all one message. This isn’t just murder. It’s a sermon, delivered with a hydraulic cannon.”

A stunned silence followed her words. The other detectives stared at her, a new, more profound horror dawning in their eyes. She had just articulated the killer’s art. As if on cue, the young tech analyst’s head snapped up from his console, his eyes wide. “Inspector! I have something.” All heads turned to him. “A video. It was just uploaded less than an hour ago to a fringe video-hosting site, one known for extremist content. The account was created this morning. The title of the video…” He swallowed hard, his finger hovering over the mouse. “The title is the symbol.”

Dubois moved to Reiss’s side. “Put it on the main screen,” he commanded, his voice a low growl. The analyst clicked, and the faces of the victims on the digital whiteboard were replaced by a black video player. The room held its breath. The play button, a simple white triangle, seemed to pulse with malice. The analyst clicked it. The screen remained black for a three full seconds, an eternity of held breath and pounding hearts. Then, a distorted, synthesized voice filled the room, a chilling, robotic monotone that was neither male nor female. It spoke a single, clear, resonant word that struck Anouk Reiss with the force of a physical blow.

“*Remplacé.*”The word hung in the air, a sterile and menacing pronouncement. Then the screen exploded into a frantic, sickly montage. Quick cuts of cranes clawing at the sky above the La Défense business district, followed by graffiti-scarred walls in a forgotten alleyway. A slow-motion shot of a crowd on the Champs-Élysées, faces blurred into a homogenous, threatening mass. The Haussmannian facades of old Paris, but filmed with a fish-eye lens, so they seemed to bulge and warp, as if diseased. Over this visual chaos, the synthesized voice continued, each word landing like a chip of ice.

“You watch the body of your city decay,” it rasped, devoid of all human inflection. “You smell the sickness in the air and call it progress. You are governed by hollow men who sell your birthright for a pittance. They invite the rot into your home, and you welcome it, mistaking the fever for warmth. They tell you this is your future. A future of concrete and glass where there was once stone and soul. A future of foreign tongues where your own is forgotten. They have replaced your identity with a globalist fantasy, and you applaud them for it.”

The images grew more aggressive. A close-up of crumbling plaster giving way to dust. A wrecking ball swinging in a silent, brutal arc. The symbol—the broken cross—burned onto the screen, superimposed over a time-lapse of a modern skyscraper being erected, its sterile grid eclipsing the sky. The voice rose slightly in its synthesized cadence, achieving a grotesque imitation of righteous fury. “We are the cure. The harsh medicine. We will excise the tumours. We will cauterize the wounds. The teacher who poisons the minds of your children with lies of a blended future… *Remplacé*. The architect who paves over your history… *Remplacé*. We do not destroy. We purify. And the purification has only just begun.”

A new image appeared, held for a disquieting length of time. It was a view of the city from above, at night, the lights glittering like a circuit board. Then the voice delivered its final, chilling promise. “The next sermon will be delivered where the city’s heart was first replaced, where the guts of old Paris were torn out for a monument to commerce and spectacle. Seek us there.” The screen flashed to a single, stark frame of the blood-spattered blackboard from Karim Al-Jamil’s classroom, then cut to absolute black.

The silence that followed was heavier and more absolute than before, a vacuum that sucked all the air from the room. It was Dubois who broke it, slamming his fist on the heavy briefing table. The sharp crack made half the room jump. “Trace it! Now!” he roared at the terrified-looking tech analyst. “The IP address, the server logs, the account, the software used for the voice—I want everything! I want to know what this bastard had for breakfast!” His rage was a blunt instrument, a desperate attempt to impose order on a reality that had just been so thoroughly violated. It was the only tool he had left against an enemy who communicated through manifestos and severed heads.

Reiss, by contrast, seemed to shrink into herself, her focus narrowing to a single point as the room erupted into a controlled chaos of barked orders and ringing phones. She replayed the words in her head. *Hollow men. Sickness. Cure. Purify.* It was the language of a zealot, but also of a profound narcissist. The killer used ‘we’, but it was a lie. The grandeur of the tone, the bespoke symbol, the singular, theatrical vision—this was the work of one person. ‘We’ was a costume, a royal affectation worn to make a lonely, bitter pathology feel like a grand crusade. This wasn't a movement. It was a one-man show.

An hour later, after the room had mostly emptied into a city-wide flurry of frantic activity, Dubois found her still staring at the blank digital whiteboard where the video had played. The initial explosion of his anger had burned out, leaving behind the exhausted, grim-faced detective he always was. “Where the city’s heart was first replaced,” he muttered, running a hand through his thinning grey hair. “Les Halles. He’s talking about the old market. They tore it all down in the seventies for the Forum des Halles. A shopping centre and a train station.” His voice was heavy with a weary disgust. “He’s going to hit a shopping mall. A public space, packed with people. This is an escalation, Anouk. A massive one.”

“He isn't just escalating the violence,” Reiss said, her voice low and distant, as if speaking from the bottom of her pool. “He’s escalating the performance. The classroom was intimate. The courier delivery was a private horror staged for an audience of one. Now he wants an audience of thousands. He’s not just a killer, Jean-Pierre. He’s a showman.” She finally looked at him, and for the first time that day, Dubois saw not just the cold discipline in her eyes, but a flicker of something else. A deep, chilling, and disturbingly clear understanding of the monster they were hunting. “And he’s just announced his next stage.”

Her own phone vibrated on the table, a sharp, angry buzz against the polished surface. It was the forensics lab. She put it on speaker. “Reiss.” The voice on the other end was Dr. Alarie, the chief medical examiner, a woman whose calm professionalism was legendary. Today, it was frayed at the edges. “Anouk, a word on your second victim, Jean-Luc Tissot. The one who was… delivered.” There was a pause. “The decapitation was post-mortem. The cause of death was the same as Al-Jamil. Hydraulic overpressure. We found traces of the same industrial fluid in what was left of his torso. But that’s not why I’m calling.” Dr. Alarie took a breath. “We found something inside him. Or rather, inside what was left. Something the pressure didn't destroy. A small, titanium cylinder, heat-shielded. It looks like a data capsule.”

Reiss and Dubois exchanged a look of sheer disbelief. A data capsule. Hidden inside a victim. “Have you opened it?” Reiss asked, her heart beginning its percussive, deep-water thump.

“We have,” Alarie confirmed. “It contains a single file. A list. It’s not long. Just twelve names. Karim Al-Jamil was the first name on the list. Jean-Luc Tissot was the second.”The line went dead, but the echo of Dr. Alarie’s words remained, hanging in the sterile air of the briefing room like radioactive dust. A list. A kill list, secreted inside a victim and delivered by a ghost. It was a new dimension of calculated cruelty, a move so audacious and arrogant it defied comprehension. For a moment, neither Reiss nor Dubois moved. The quiet hum of the servers and the distant, frantic ringing of phones seemed to belong to another world. They were in the killer's world now, a place where human beings were not just targets, but vessels for messages.

Dubois was the first to react, his body coiling with a surge of furious energy. He snatched his coat from the back of a chair, his movements jerky and powerful. “Get Alarie to send that list over. Now,” he barked at a nearby officer, who scrambled to comply. “I want every name on that list found and put into protective custody within the hour. I don't care if they’re having dinner with the President, I want a uniform on their doorstep five minutes ago. Move!” His voice was a whip-crack, galvanizing the residual shock in the room into a frenzy of action. For Dubois, the list was a gift. It was a tangible, actionable piece of intelligence in a case that had so far been nothing but abstract horror. It was a chance to get ahead of the monster.

Reiss, however, felt a different, colder reality crystallize within her. She walked slowly back to the digital whiteboard, where the killer’s sigil still pulsed faintly like a dark star. Dubois saw a target list; she saw a script. Talia hadn’t made a mistake. He hadn’t accidentally left them a clue. He had deliberately armed them with the knowledge of his future crimes. He was inviting them to the show, handing them a programme, confident that they were powerless to stop the performance. He wanted the police to find these ten people. He wanted the terror to spread from the anonymous victims to the named ones, to let them live with the knowledge that they were on a list, marked for a uniquely grotesque death. He was poisoning the city with fear, one name at a time.

Moments later, the list appeared on the screen, transmitted from the forensics lab. Twelve names, typed in a simple, sans-serif font.
1.  Karim Al-Jamil. History Teacher. *[Deceased]*
2.  Jean-Luc Tissot. Urban Planner. *[Deceased]*
3.  Dr. Lena Petrova. Sociologist, Sorbonne University. Specialization: Post-colonial migration patterns.
4.  Marc Vasseur. CEO, ‘Verba Lingua’ Tech. Creator of a popular real-time translation app.
5.  Ayaan Fariq. Imam, Grand Mosque of Paris. Known for progressive, interfaith outreach.
6.  Chloé-Marie Bertrand. Artist. Her latest exhibition, ‘Visages de Paris’, featured portraits of naturalized citizens.
And so it continued. A human rights lawyer. A celebrity chef whose fusion cuisine was celebrated as the taste of modern France. A journalist who had written a book debunking the ‘Grand Remplacement’ theory. A film director. Each name was a pillar of a new, multicultural France. Each was a direct refutation of the killer’s ideology. Talia wasn’t just killing people; he was trying to assassinate a vision of the future.

The briefing room became the nerve centre of a city-wide race against time. The ten names and faces, pulled from public records and social media, now stared out from the whiteboard, a gallery of the condemned. The logistics were a nightmare.
