Outside the room’s soundproofed walls, the Prefecture had erupted into a symphony of controlled chaos, the dozen locations Anouk had extracted from Lucien now the targets of a massive, city-wide tactical operation. Phones rang, orders were barked, and units were dispatched with a speed and fury born of sheer, adrenaline-laced relief. But inside the lab, there was only stillness. Anouk leaned back against the examination table, the sudden absence of conflict leaving a vacuum in its wake. She felt hollowed out, scoured clean by the corrosive act of looking into a soul like Lucien’s and using its own pathetic misery as a weapon against it. She had won, but she had paid for the victory by visiting a place within herself she never knew existed, a place of cold, precise, psychological violence.

Dubois stood frozen for a moment, staring at her with an expression that was no longer just fear or concern. It was awe. He had just witnessed an interrogation that would be the stuff of legend at the Quai des Orfèvres, a masterclass in psychological demolition performed not with threats or force, but with the devastating, pinpoint application of the truth. He saw not just his partner, but a woman who had descended into the monster’s labyrinth and emerged, not unscathed, but with the beast’s head in her hand. He slowly lowered the phone from his ear, the reports of teams arriving at mosques and hostels now a secondary concern to the quiet, exhausted figure at the center of the room. He had wanted to protect her, but he had just watched her become the most dangerous weapon in their entire arsenal.

The news from the field trickled in, painting a grim picture of Lucien’s final, desperate contingency. His ‘sermons’ were real. At the Rue Myrha mosque, a tactical team found a crude but lethal device in the boiler room: a high-pressure canister of industrial solvent wired to a propane tank, set to be triggered by the same cellular network as all the others. In the basement of the Saint-Denis workers’ hostel, it was a drum of corrosive chemicals rigged to a pump that would have flooded the ground floor. Each of the twelve locations held a similar story of amateurish construction paired with a professional’s understanding of terror. They were not the elegant, bespoke weapons of his earlier work; they were tantrums, spasms of violence designed for maximum chaos, the last spiteful acts of a man who knew he was cornered. And they were all still active, all still listening for the steady, rhythmic pulse of Anouk’s heart.

Varennes, ever the pragmatist, brought them all crashing back to the central, terrifying reality. He approached Anouk, his face etched with a new urgency. “Inspector, your gambit worked. We have the targets. My teams are on-site, ready to disarm. But they cannot proceed. Each device is still linked to the network. They are all still linked to *you*.” He gestured to the green light on her wrist, which seemed to pulse brighter in the sterile room. “He gave you the locations, but he didn’t give you the key. Without the decryption code for the network, we can’t send a system-wide ‘safe’ command. We can’t build the spoofer. We are still trapped in his game, and you are still the board.” The brief flicker of triumph died. The city was safe from a dozen explosions only as long as Anouk’s heart continued to beat in a calm, steady rhythm. The manacle was still locked.

A profound, soul-deep weariness settled over Anouk. She looked at her wrist, at the angry red line the band had already etched into her skin. It was a brand, marking her as his. She thought of the pool, of the clean, chlorinated void. It felt a lifetime away, a memory from someone else’s life. The water was no longer a sanctuary; it was a crime scene, the place where she had finally met the ghost who had haunted her for half her life, only to become a ghost herself, trapped between the world of the living and a network of sleeping bombs. She had done her job. She had stopped him. But she was still his last creation, his final, living masterpiece of terror.

Then, a breakthrough. A call came in from the team leader at the Quai de Valmy cultural centre. “Commandant Varennes, we have the device secured. It’s another pressure-based system. But the control unit… it’s different. More complex. There’s a diagnostic port, and a micro-SD card is still in the slot.” A current of electricity shot through the room. It was the hubris of the creator, the artist so proud of his work he couldn’t resist leaving his notes behind. Varennes’s voice was tight with controlled excitement. “Do not touch it. Bag the entire unit and bring it here. Top priority. It’s to be treated like a live organ for transplant. Go.” The card was a long shot, a desperate hope, but in a game where the odds were stacked so impossibly high, it was the only move they had left.

The next hour was the longest of Anouk’s life. She sat in silence, a living metronome, while the city held its breath and the best minds of the French police state threw themselves at a tiny piece of plastic and silicon. The technicians worked in a hushed, frantic ballet, their fingers flying across keyboards, their faces illuminated by the glow of their screens. Finally, one of them let out a sharp, triumphant cry. “I’m in! It’s all here. The source code for the network, the encryption keys, the algorithm for the biometric signal… it’s all on the card.” The collective sigh of relief in the room was a physical wave. Varennes’s team began to work, translating the raw data into a machine that could lie, a spoofer that could perfectly mimic the rhythm of her life.

Varennes approached her at last, holding a small, silver box connected by a wire to a laptop. His face was beaded with sweat, but his hands were rock steady. “Inspector. We are ready. This device will take over the signal. It will broadcast a perfect replica of your heartbeat to the network. For the five seconds it takes to switch from you to the machine, the network will be blind. It is the most dangerous five seconds we have. I need you to remain absolutely still. Breathe in, breathe out. On my mark.” He knelt before her, his fingers hovering over the clasp of her bracelet. The room fell into a silence so profound Anouk could hear the blood pulsing in her own ears. “Now,” Varennes said. He pressed the release. The clasp sprang open.

For five eternal seconds, Anouk Reiss was untethered, a free woman who held the fate of a dozen locations in the space between her heartbeats. Varennes lifted the bracelet from her arm. The cold air hit the raw skin on her wrist, a shocking, liberating sensation. A technician hit a key. “Signal stable! The spoofer is live! The network is secure!” he shouted, his voice cracking with relief. Varennes placed the bracelet on a sterile steel tray. Its little green light, which had been the sun of Anouk’s terrifying new universe, flickered once, and then went dark. It was over. She was free. Anouk looked down at the red, angry mark on her wrist, a physical scar left by a phantom. She slowly, deliberately, flexed her fingers, feeling the strange, forgotten lightness of her own hand. Dubois was suddenly beside her, wrapping a heavy wool blanket around her shoulders. The simple, uncomplicated warmth of it was a shock, an anchor to a world she thought she had lost forever. The war was over. The city was safe. And Anouk Reiss, cold, hollowed-out, and irrevocably changed, could finally go home.## Chapter 10

The blanket Dubois draped over her shoulders was a heavy, grounding weight, a simple anchor of wool and warmth in a world that had lost all its bearings. In the sudden, profound silence of the laboratory, the absence of the pulsing green light was a palpable void. Anouk looked at her wrist, at the angry red indentation, the raw skin where the manacle had been. It was the only physical proof of the phantom limb she had carried, the bomb she had become. The technicians and officers around her began to move again, their relief manifesting not in cheers, but in a quiet, collective exhalation, the sound of a city no longer holding its breath. They averted their eyes from her, not out of disrespect, but out of a kind of holy terror. She had walked through a fire none of them could comprehend and had emerged on the other side, marked but whole. Varennes gave her a single, sharp nod—the highest form of praise from a man like him—and then turned his attention back to his work, dismantling the last remnants of Lucien Marchal’s symphony.

The drive home through the nascent dawn was a journey through a pane of glass. Paris was waking up. The steel shutters of boulangeries were rattling open, street sweepers were washing the grime of the night from the gutters, and the first tired-looking commuters were descending into the mouths of the metro. It was a city blissfully, beautifully unaware of the dozen apocalypses it had so narrowly avoided. Anouk watched it all pass by, feeling like a ghost haunting the edges of her own life. She was a secret the city would never know it kept. Dubois sat beside her in the passenger seat this time, letting another detective drive. He didn't speak, didn't offer platitudes or ask how she felt. The silence was a shared space of respect. He had seen the cold, precise lethality she had deployed in the interrogation, the terrifying focus of her final confrontation. He knew that the woman sitting next to him was not the same one he had pulled from the pool of her own grief just a few days ago. The ordeal hadn't broken her; it had forged her into something harder, something he wasn’t sure he entirely understood anymore.

Her apartment was just as she had left it, a capsule of a life that no longer felt like her own. When the door clicked shut behind her, the silence was no longer a comfort. It was an accusation. It was filled with the ghosts of the dead, the terror of the living, and the reedy, worshipful voice of a boy who had waited sixteen years to be seen. She walked into the bathroom and stood before the mirror, taking stock. Her eyes were black-rimmed with an exhaustion so deep it felt geological. A raw, red scratch snaked across her cheek from where Lucien’s nails had raked her in the final struggle. And on her wrist, the angry, red bracelet mark, a stigma of her ordeal. This was the wreckage. This was what was left. She turned on the tap and splashed cold water on her face, the sensation a pale imitation of the violent immersion that had defined the last 24 hours. The water no longer promised purity. It was just water.

She didn’t sleep. She sat on her sofa as the sun climbed higher, casting long shadows across her living room floor, and watched the city come fully alive. Around noon, her phone buzzed. It was Dubois. His voice was tired but steady, the familiar gravelly tone of a cop back on solid ground. “The last device was disarmed an hour ago. It’s over, Anouk. It’s all just paperwork now.” He paused. “He’s been transferred. He’ll be buried so deep in the system he’ll forget what sunlight looks like. He's just a file now.” Anouk knew he was trying to offer her closure, to reduce the monster to a bureaucratic footnote. But it was too late. Lucien Marchal was no longer just a man or a file. He was a piece of her history, a phantom limb that would ache on cold nights, a dark whisper in the back of her mind. He had failed in his grand mission, but he had succeeded in his deepest, most pathetic desire: he had made himself a permanent part of her.

Two days later, she woke before the sun, the old rhythm pulling her from a shallow, restless sleep. The scratch on her cheek was beginning to heal. The red mark on her wrist was fading to a dull, bruised purple. She dressed not in her uniform, but in her swimsuit. She picked up her bag, walked out into the cold, dark morning, and made her way to the Piscine Pontoise. The building was open, alive again. The familiar smell of chlorine was a comfort and a threat. Jean-Pierre was at the front desk. He saw her and his face went pale, his eyes wide with a mixture of fear and reverence. He looked at her like she was a saint who had just stepped down from a stained-glass window. She gave him a curt, dismissive nod and walked past him, her focus on the double doors that led to the pool.

She stood on the edge of the deck, looking down the long, sapphire lane. It was exactly as it had always been, the water a calm, inviting blue, the tiled cross a familiar promise at the far end. But it was irrevocably changed, haunted. This was no longer a sanctuary. It was a battlefield. It was a tomb. It was the stage for a final, terrible act. She could feel the memory of Lucien’s weight, the silent, brutal struggle in the depths, the ghost of his hatred. The water was a lie. It had promised her a clean, chlorinated void, but it had become the very thing she could never wash away. For a long moment, she stood perfectly still, wondering if she could ever enter it again, if the place that had once been her only peace was now lost to her forever.

Then, she stepped onto the starting block. She did not hesitate. Her body coiled into the familiar posture of readiness, her toes gripping the edge. She took a breath. It was not a breath of meditation, but of defiance. She was not here to forget. She was here to reclaim. She dove. The water was a shock, cold and absolute, but it was not an enemy. It was just water. She broke the surface and began to swim, her arms pulling, her legs kicking, her body a familiar, powerful machine. Stroke, kick, breathe. The mantra was different now. It was no longer about escape. It was a statement of survival. Stroke: *I am here.* Kick: *I am still here.* Breathe: *I will always be here.* The water could not wash the filth away, but it could bear her up. It could hold her. She was a swimmer, carving a path not through a quiet, blue void, but through the wreckage of her own history, moving forward one powerful, relentless, and deliberate stroke at a time.Her first lap was a fight. The water, once a frictionless medium for her meditative violence, now seemed thick with memory, clinging to her like a shroud. With every pull of her arms, she felt the phantom weight of Lucien’s body, the desperate scrabble of his fingers against her skin. With every kick, she felt the sickening grind of his dislocated thumb, the terrible, intimate act of breaking another human being. The muffled, percussive thump of her own heart was no longer a comforting rhythm; it was a timer, the echo of a dead man’s switch she had worn on her own skin. She swam through a ghost-choir of his whispered words, through the image of Karim Al-Jamil’s ruined classroom, through the silent, screaming terror in Chloé-Marie Bertrand’s eyes. This was not a cleansing. It was an exorcism by immersion, a forced march through the battlefield of her own trauma.

By the tenth lap, something shifted. The ghosts did not vanish, but they receded, their screams fading to whispers, their faces blurring into the blue depths below. They were becoming part of the water, part of the landscape of this place. Her body, acting on a wisdom deeper than thought, found its rhythm again. The burn in her muscles was real, a clean, honest pain that anchored her in the present. The rasp of her own breathing was the sound of life, a defiant noise in a place that had been consecrated to death. She was not escaping the memories. She was outlasting them. She was swimming through them and out the other side, her body a relentless engine of survival. When she finally touched the wall for the last time, her limbs trembling with an exhaustion that was both physical and spiritual, she did not feel clean. She felt emptied. And in that emptiness, there was a sliver of space to begin again.

Her return to the Quai des Orfèvres was a quiet, suffocating ordeal. The bustling headquarters, once a place of gruff camaraderie and shared purpose, now felt like a foreign country. Colleagues who would normally greet her with a sarcastic remark or a weary nod now fell silent as she passed, their gazes a mixture of awe and something that looked disturbingly like fear. They made way for her in the corridors as if she were a visiting dignitary or a ghost haunting her old office. She had become a myth, a legend whispered over stale coffee and cigarettes. The Inspector who went into the water with a monster and came out wearing his heart. The story, already embellished, had made her untouchable, isolating her more completely than any secure room ever could. She was no longer just a colleague. She was a monument to a horror they had all witnessed from a safe distance.

Dubois found her staring out the window of her small office, looking down at the grey, sluggish waters of the Seine. He didn’t knock, just entered and closed the door behind him, creating a small pocket of their old reality in the changed landscape of the new. He placed a steaming cup of coffee on her desk, the gesture so familiar it was almost painful. He didn’t sit, but leaned against the filing cabinet, his expression unreadable. For a long moment, he said nothing, simply allowing the silence to settle between them. He was studying her, trying to reconcile the woman he had known for a decade with the cold, precise weapon he had seen on the monitor, the avenging angel who had risen from the water.

Finally, he spoke, his voice lower than usual, stripped of its usual bluster. “The Prefect wants to give you a commendation. The Médaille d’honneur. They’re talking about a promotion, a desk job. Head of a new task force. Anything you want, Anouk. You can write your own ticket.” He was offering her a way out, an honorable discharge from the front lines, a quiet, administrative peace. It was his way of trying to put her back in a box, to protect her, to undo what had been done. He was offering her a different kind of sanctuary.

Anouk turned from the window, a small, wry smile touching her lips. It didn't quite reach her eyes. “And spend the rest of my life shuffling papers, Jean-Pierre? Drowning in reports instead of water? No.” She picked up the coffee, the warmth of the cheap ceramic a small, grounding comfort. “I’m a homicide detective. It’s what I do. It’s who I am.” Dubois held her gaze, and in it, he saw no trace of the broken, traumatized victim he had feared he would find. He saw a scar, deep and permanent, but he also saw the familiar, unyielding iron that had always been there, now tempered into something even stronger. The fear in his eyes was replaced by a slow, dawning understanding, a profound and weary respect. He gave a single, short nod. The offer was withdrawn. The old world, or something like it, clicked back into place.

Her phone rang, the sound sharp and mundane in the quiet office. It was the central dispatch. Anouk answered, her voice its usual flat, professional tone. “Reiss.” She listened for a moment, her expression unchanging. “Alright. On our way.” She hung up and reached for her coat. Dubois raised an eyebrow, a silent question. “A body,” she said, her voice matter-of-fact. “An accountant found in his apartment in the 13th. Looks like a robbery gone wrong. Pathetic and messy.” She shrugged into her coat, the familiar weight settling on her shoulders. For the first time in days, it felt right. She was no longer a victim, a target, or a myth. She was a cop going to a crime scene. As they walked out of the office and back into the loud, chaotic hum of the Brigade Criminelle, she glanced down at her wrist. The bruised mark was still there, a faint, purple ghost beneath her watch. It was a part of her now, a map of where she had been. But it was not a chain. It was just a scar. The city was still filled with filth, with pathetic, messy, sordid tragedies. The water was still a lie. But she no longer needed it to be true. She walked out of the building and into the grey Parisian drizzle, a detective heading back to work, her eyes clear and focused on the unyielding, un-washable truth of the world she had chosen.

parts.text:
The water was a lie. It promised purity, a clean, chlorinated void where the city and its filth couldn't follow. For Anouk Reiss, the long, sapphire lane of the Piscine Pontoise was a sanctuary, a place of rhythmic, meditative violence against the unyielding medium. Stroke, kick, breathe. The world reduced to muscle burn and the muffled, percussive thump of her own heart. She was not DI Reiss in here. She was a body in motion, a swimmer, carving a path through the quiet blue. The tiled cross at the end of the lane approached, blurred, and then sharpened. She executed a perfect tumble turn, a fluid coil and release that sent a silent shockwave through the water. For a moment, suspended upside down, the submerged lights of the old pool looked like distant, drowned stars. This was peace. The only peace she ever really knew.

Stroke, kick, breathe. The mantra that had taken her from the junior leagues in Paris to the edge of national recognition, before the realities of a different life, a different calling, had pulled her from the water and onto the blood-spattered pavement. But she never truly left. Every morning before the sun bothered to climb over the zinc-and-slate rooftops, she was here. Washing the day before away. Or trying to. Today’s residue was particularly foul. A domestic dispute in the 15th that had ended with a porcelain figurine and a caved-in skull. The killer had been wearing his wife’s floral apron. Reiss could still smell the coppery tang of blood mixed with the cloying scent of cheap perfume. The water was supposed to wash that away. But the memory was greasy. It clung.

A frantic waving from the side of the pool broke her rhythm. It was Jean-Pierre, the young lifeguard, his face pale and tight. He was pointing at his own ear, then at the front desk. The phone. A knot of ice formed in Reiss’s gut, instantly negating the warmth generated by the exercise. Calls to the pool were never good. They meant the world had refused to wait. She swam to the edge, her movements suddenly graceless, urgent. Pulling herself out, water sluicing from her lean, powerful frame, she didn't bother with a towel. The chill on her skin was a prelude.

“Inspector?” Jean-Pierre offered the cordless phone like it was a venomous snake. “It’s Inspector Dubois. He said it’s… important.”

Reiss took it, the cold plastic a shock against her wet hand. “Reiss.”

“Anouk. Sorry to pull you out of the soup.” Her partner’s voice was gravelly, scraped raw by a lifetime of Gauloises and late nights. “But you need to see this.”

“Another domestic?” she asked, her own voice flat.

A pause. A long, weary sigh crackled down the line. “No. Not even close. This is… something else. Something new. Meet me at Lycée Charlemagne. In the Marais.”

“A school?” The ice in her stomach spread to her limbs. Schools were supposed to be like her pool. Sanctuaries. “What’s the situation?”

“The situation,” Dubois rasped, and she could hear the grimace in his voice, “is that a teacher is dead. And the first responders are calling the weapon a ‘splurge-gun’. You’re going to want your strongest stomach for this one. And Anouk? Hurry.”

The line went dead. Splurge-gun. The word was ugly, cartoonish, and utterly terrifying. It didn't belong in the vocabulary of a Parisian homicide detective. Reiss stood dripping on the cold tiles, the lie of the water evaporating around her, leaving her exposed and cold. The city had found her again.

The drive across Paris was a smear of grey rain and blurred neon. Dubois sat hunched in the passenger seat of her unassuming Peugeot, the glow of his phone illuminating the deep-set lines of exhaustion on his face. He’d been at the scene for an hour already. He smelled of wet wool and the acidic scent of pure dread.

“The victim is Karim Al-Jamil,” Dubois said, not looking up from his screen. “History teacher. Forty-two. Married, two kids. By all accounts, a saint. The kind of teacher kids actually like. Ran the debate club, coached the girls’ football team.”

“And the weapon?” Reiss kept her eyes on the road, the windscreen wipers beating a frantic, hypnotic rhythm.

Dubois finally looked over, his eyes dark and troubled. “You’ll see. Forensics is baffled. It’s not a firearm. No casing, no entry wound in the traditional sense. It’s… high pressure. Catastrophically high pressure. The scene is… it’s like an abattoir. But an abstract one. The ME said it looks like the man was turned into a piece of modern art. His words.”

Reiss’s hands tightened on the wheel. She hated it when they got poetic. It meant the reality was too grotesque for plain language. “Motive? Robbery?”

“Nothing was taken. Wallet, watch, phone, all there. He was working late, grading papers in his classroom. Alone.” Dubois swiped through his phone again. “This is the part that gets weird. Or weirder.”

The Lycée Charlemagne loomed ahead, a grand old fortress of learning, its stone façade streaked with rain and bathed in the lurid, strobing colours of police lights. The incongruity was sickening. Reiss parked behind a row of emergency vehicles, the chatter of radios cutting through the steady hiss of the downpour. A perimeter had been established, a few students and residents held back by uniformed officers, their faces a mixture of curiosity and horror.

“The classroom is on the second floor,” Dubois grunted, pulling the collar of his coat up. “The principal found him. He’s in the nurse’s office, sedated. Useless.”

They didn't need the principal. The scene told its own story. The hallway was unnaturally quiet, the usual scent of chalk dust and teenage anxiety replaced with the sharp, metallic odour of blood and disinfectant. A forensics officer in a white paper suit nodded at them as they ducked under the tape. “Inspectors. Be prepared.”

The classroom was a tableau of interrupted academia. Posters of the French Revolution and Enlightenment philosophers lined the walls. A stack of neatly corrected essays sat on the edge of the desk, the top one titled ‘Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité: An Ideal or a Reality?’. And in the centre of the room, the source of the smell, the epicentre of the horror. Karim Al-Jamil, or what was left of him, was slumped in his chair. Dubois hadn't been exaggerating. There was no single point of impact. His entire torso was a mangled, shredded ruin of flesh and fabric, blasted outward against the blackboard behind him. The chalk dust had mixed with the spray, creating a grotesque, pastel-coloured fresco of annihilation. ‘Splurge-gun’ was a horrifyingly accurate descriptor. It looked as though he had been inflated and then simply… burst.

Reiss felt the bile rise in her throat. She swallowed it down, her swimmer’s discipline kicking in. Detach. Observe. The desk was untouched, save for the spray. The papers were pristine. The victim’s hands were resting in his lap, almost peaceful, a bizarre counterpoint to the devastation of his body. She walked the perimeter of the room, her eyes scanning every detail. The open window. The faint scuff marks near the door. The absolute lack of any struggle.

“He was taken by surprise,” she murmured, her voice a low hum. “Sat at his desk, and then… this.”

“From the doorway, we think,” Dubois said, pointing with his pen. “Maximum effective range seems to be about three meters. Whatever it is, it’s not a long-distance weapon.”

Reiss knelt, her eyes level with the blasted chair. She saw it then. Tucked just under the victim’s shoe, a small, laminated card. She motioned to a forensics tech. “Bag that. Carefully.”

The tech used a pair of tweezers to lift the card. It was a simple business card, but on its reverse was a crudely printed symbol: a stylized, broken cross inside a circle. And beneath it, a single, typed word.

*Remplacé.*

Replaced.

“What the hell does that mean?” Dubois muttered, peering over her shoulder.

Reiss stood up, a cold certainty beginning to dawn. It felt different from the sordid, pathetic motives she usually dealt with. This wasn't passion or greed. It was ideology. It was a statement. “It means this isn’t over,” she said, her voice barely a whisper. “This is the opening line.”

Her phone buzzed. It was a call from the central dispatch. Her blood ran cold. It was too soon for another body.

“DI Reiss,” she answered, her tone clipped.

“Inspector,” the dispatcher’s voice was strained, high-pitched. “We have… another situation. It’s connected to your scene at the Lycée.”

“How?” Dubois asked, moving closer to the phone.

“A woman. Élise Moreau. In the 4th arrondissement. She’s a teacher at Lycée Charlemagne. A friend of the victim. She called police half an hour ago, hysterical. Said a courier had just delivered a package. Said it was from… from Karim Al-Jamil.”

Reiss felt the floor drop out from under her. The package. The friend. The post. This was the other part of the ritual.

“She wouldn't open the door for the first patrol car,” the dispatcher continued, his voice cracking. “They had to break it down. Inspector… the package contained a human head.”

Dubois swore, a long, heartfelt string of profanities that was almost a prayer. Reiss felt nothing. Just the vast, cold emptiness of the deep end of the pool. The lie of the water. This killer wasn’t just murdering people. They were weaponizing grief, turning friendship into a vessel for horror. They were posting the shrapnel of their hatred directly into the hearts of the people left behind. And that symbol, that word… *Remplacé*. This was a crusade. A declaration of war against people like Karim Al-Jamil. People this monster, this Talia, believed were replacing the ‘true’ France. Reiss looked at the ruin in the chair, then at the blackboard where the phrase ‘Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité’ was still faintly visible beneath the spray of blood and tissue. This wasn't just murder. It was a message, written in the most obscene ink imaginable, and it was addressed to the entire world. And she, DI Anouk Reiss, was the one who had to read it.

The drive to the 4th was a descent into a deeper circle of hell. The rain had intensified, lashing against the windscreen as if trying to wash the city clean, a futile effort. Dubois was silent now, the phone call having stripped away his gallows humour, leaving only a grim, stony resolve. Reiss felt a strange, hyper-aware calm settle over her. The shock was a physical thing, a carapace of ice forming over her nerves. It was the only way to function. The pool had taught her to hold her breath; the job had taught her to hold her soul, to keep it from breaking the surface and drowning in the filth. They were no longer just chasing a killer. They were pursuing a phantom who could be in two places at once, whose cruelty was a form of architecture, building monuments of despair.

Élise Moreau’s apartment was on the third floor of a handsome Haussmannian building on the Rue de Rivoli, its wrought-iron balconies overlooking a street of chic boutiques and bustling cafes. The dissonance was nauseating. Inside, the air was thick with a new kind of silence, the sound of a life that has been irrevocably shattered. A medic was leading a woman, presumably Moreau, towards a waiting ambulance. She was wrapped in a shock blanket, her face a blank mask of incomprehension, her eyes fixed on something in the middle distance that no one else could see. She didn't make a sound. The loudest screams are often the ones you cannot hear.

Reiss and Dubois entered the living room. It was a scholar’s haven, books piled on every surface, prints of classical art on the walls, a half-finished cup of tea growing cold on a small table. It smelled of old paper, lemon, and fear. And in the centre of the polished herringbone floor sat a simple cardboard courier box. It had been torn open, the flaps splayed like a grotesque flower. The forensics team had already cordoned it off, but the violation was permanent. It was an object of pure malevolence, an invader from a nightmare dimension dropped into the heart of a peaceful life. Reiss didn't need to look inside. The presence of it was enough. The sight of the cheerful, generic courier logo on the side of the box, smeared with the fingerprints of the hysterical recipient, was more obscene than the contents it had held.

“The delivery was made forty-five minutes ago. A man in a generic courier uniform. We’re pulling traffic camera footage, but my guess is he’ll be a ghost,” a junior detective reported, his own face pale. “The sender’s address was listed as Lycée Charlemagne. The sender’s name…” he trailed off, glancing at the manifest in his hand. “Karim Al-Jamil.”

Dubois let out a breath that was half-curse, half-sob. “He weaponized his ghost. He sent a dead man to deliver a nightmare to his best friend.” He looked at Reiss, his eyes pleading for an explanation that didn't exist. “What kind of monster does this? What kind of mind even conceives of it?”

Reiss’s gaze was fixed on the delivery label. The cold, disciplined part of her brain was working, connecting the pieces, ignoring the screaming protest from the rest of her humanity. The timing. The logistics. This wasn't a crime of passion. It was an operation. It required planning, resources, and a complete absence of anything resembling a soul. This killer had a list. They had a schedule.

A forensics officer, a man Reiss had known for a decade, approached them. His usual morbid cheerfulness was gone. “Anouk. The head… it’s a male, Caucasian, probably in his fifties. We’ve already run a preliminary facial recognition scan against the national database. We have a hit.” He took a deep breath. “His name is Jean-Luc Tissot. He was reported missing by his wife two days ago.”

“What was his profession?” Reiss asked, the icy carapace inside her growing thicker, colder.

The officer looked down at his tablet. “He was a city planner. Head of the Urban Renewal project for the 19th arrondissement.”

*Remplacé*. Replaced. The word echoed in the sudden, ringing silence of Reiss’s mind. A history teacher of Algerian descent, a symbol of the new France. A city planner, responsible for literally changing the face of the city, for renewing, for… replacing the old. The logic was perverse, insane, but it was there. It was a pattern. The killer wasn’t just targeting people; they were targeting ideas embodied by people. They were editing reality with a high-pressure hose and a butcher’s knife.

“There will be another card,” Reiss said, her voice a dead monotone. She walked over to the forensics team working on the body part, now respectfully covered. “Check the packaging. Check the box. It will be there.”

It took them less than a minute. Tucked into the bottom of the cardboard box, beneath the blood-soaked packing material, was another laminated card. The same as the first. The broken cross inside a circle. And beneath it, the same chilling, single word.

*Remplacé.*

Reiss stared at the identical cards in the evidence bags—one from a classroom, one from a box that held a human head. It wasn’t just a signature. It was a receipt. A proof of purchase for a life taken. She looked from the card to the stunned faces of the officers around her, to the empty space where Élise Moreau had stood. This killer didn't just leave a body. They created a blast radius of trauma, sending shrapnel into the lives of everyone connected to the victim. Karim Al-Jamil was the explosion. Élise Moreau was the collateral damage. And Jean-Luc Tissot… he was the ammunition for the next round. The cold certainty hit her like a physical blow. This wasn't two murders. It was a single, continuous, horrifying process. And it was far from finished.

## Chapter 2

The headquarters of the Brigade Criminelle at 36, quai des Orfèvres was a humming hive of controlled panic. What had begun as a whisper from a lifeguard’s phone at dawn had, by noon, become a roar that consumed every resource the city’s most elite detective unit could command. The rain continued its assault on the historic building’s windows, but inside, the storm was one of data. Phones rang with a shrill, incessant urgency, uniformed officers ferried files and coffee, and the air grew thick with the scents of wet coats, ozone from the servers, and a city-wide anxiety that had seeped through the stone walls. In the media, they were already being given names: the Splurge-Gun Killer, the Blackboard Butcher. But here, in the main briefing room, they were simply called *Remplacé*.

Reiss and Dubois stood before a vast digital whiteboard, its surface a chaotic mosaic of horror. The faces of Karim Al-Jamil and Jean-Luc Tissot stared out, frozen in time from their ID photos, vibrant and unaware. Next to them were crime scene photos—the abstract horror of the classroom, the stark violation of the courier box. In the centre, glowing like a toxic sigil, was the crudely drawn symbol of the broken cross in its circle. The two laminated cards were displayed side-by-side, their single, chilling word repeated like a drumbeat. Every detective in the room, from the most jaded veteran to the greenest rookie, looked at the board with the same mixture of revulsion and grim focus. This was not a crime they had ever seen before. It felt like a tear in the fabric of their reality.

The Prefect of Police himself had made an appearance, a sleek, political animal in a tailored suit who spoke of containing public fear and managing the media narrative. He used words like ‘unprecedented’ and ‘barbaric’, but his eyes betrayed a more primal fear: that of a man who felt the ground shifting beneath his feet. He wanted answers, but more than that, he wanted control. He looked at Reiss, his gaze lingering, knowing her reputation for navigating the darkest currents of the human psyche. "Inspector Reiss," he had said, his voice a low command. "Find this animal. Before he writes his next line." The Prefect’s visit had left a film of political desperation over everything, another layer of grime the water in the pool could never wash away.

A young tech analyst, barely old enough to shave, stood by the board, trying to lend scientific order to the madness. “The term ‘Remplacé’ is, as you’d expect, a direct reference to the ‘Grand Remplacement’,” he explained, his voice tight. “The conspiracy theory popular in far-right circles that native French populations are being deliberately replaced by non-European immigrants. It’s the cornerstone of dozens of extremist ideologies. The symbol, however… that’s new. We’ve run it through every database—Interpol, Europol, our own domestic intelligence archives. It doesn’t match any known group, neo-Nazi, nationalist, or otherwise. It’s bespoke. Our killer has his own logo.”

Reiss listened, her mind a still, deep pool of concentration. While others saw a political theory, she saw the architecture of a psychosis. It wasn't about politics, not really. It was about a narcissistic rage so profound it needed to invent an entire cosmology to justify its own violence. The killer wasn’t a soldier in a war; they were the god of their own filthy religion, and these murders were their acts of creation. Internally, she had already given the killer a name. Talia. It was the name of a cruel ice-queen from a storybook she’d read as a child, a sorceress who delighted in turning living things into frozen, grotesque statues. It was better than the sterile ‘subject’ or ‘perpetrator’. It gave the evil a shape, a thing she could hunt, rather than just an idea she had to endure.

“We have a preliminary analysis of the… residue… from the Al-Jamil scene,” a forensics liaison announced, her face grim. The room fell silent. “It’s not a projectile weapon. There was no explosive. The ME’s report confirms the victim’s body was subjected to a catastrophic hydraulic overpressure event. We found trace elements of polyalkylene glycol and phosphate esters in the blast pattern. It’s a specialized, high-performance hydraulic fluid. The kind used in heavy industrial and demolition machinery—high-pressure cutters, rams, that sort of thing. The weapon is almost certainly a custom-built device, a hydraulic cannon. It’s not something you buy. It’s something you build, if you have the expertise.”

Dubois let out a low whistle, rubbing the grey stubble on his jaw. “So, we are looking for a disgruntled engineer? A demolition expert with a god complex and a subscription to a racist newsletter? Someone with access to a workshop and the materials to build this… this monstrosity?” It was a practical, solid line of inquiry, a piece of firm ground in a swamp of insanity. But Reiss was already a step beyond the practical. She was looking at the board, at the victims, at the weapon’s composition, and she was seeing the poetry of it. The terrible, sickening poetry.

“It’s not just the tool he used,” she said, her voice quiet but carrying across the room. “It’s part of the message. Jean-Luc Tissot was a city planner. He headed an Urban Renewal project. He literally tore down the old to make way for the new. To… replace it.” She let the word hang in the air. “Talia uses the fluid of demolition to demolish a man who taught a new history of France. The symbolism is the point. The weapon, the victim, the word—it’s all one message. This isn’t just murder. It’s a sermon, delivered with a hydraulic cannon.”

A stunned silence followed her words. The other detectives stared at her, a new, more profound horror dawning in their eyes. She had just articulated the killer’s art. As if on cue, the young tech analyst’s head snapped up from his console, his eyes wide. “Inspector! I have something.” All heads turned to him. “A video. It was just uploaded less than an hour ago to a fringe video-hosting site, one known for extremist content. The account was created this morning. The title of the video…” He swallowed hard, his finger hovering over the mouse. “The title is the symbol.”

Dubois moved to Reiss’s side. “Put it on the main screen,” he commanded, his voice a low growl. The analyst clicked, and the faces of the victims on the digital whiteboard were replaced by a black video player. The room held its breath. The play button, a simple white triangle, seemed to pulse with malice. The analyst clicked it. The screen remained black for a three full seconds, an eternity of held breath and pounding hearts. Then, a distorted, synthesized voice filled the room, a chilling, robotic monotone that was neither male nor female. It spoke a single, clear, resonant word that struck Anouk Reiss with the force of a physical blow.

“*Remplacé.*”

The word hung in the air, a sterile and menacing pronouncement. Then the screen exploded into a frantic, sickly montage. Quick cuts of cranes clawing at the sky above the La Défense business district, followed by graffiti-scarred walls in a forgotten alleyway. A slow-motion shot of a crowd on the Champs-Élysées, faces blurred into a homogenous, threatening mass. The Haussmannian facades of old Paris, but filmed with a fish-eye lens, so they seemed to bulge and warp, as if diseased. Over this visual chaos, the synthesized voice continued, each word landing like a chip of ice.

“You watch the body of your city decay,” it rasped, devoid of all human inflection. “You smell the sickness in the air and call it progress. You are governed by hollow men who sell your birthright for a pittance. They invite the rot into your home, and you welcome it, mistaking the fever for warmth. They tell you this is your future. A future of concrete and glass where there was once stone and soul. A future of foreign tongues where your own is forgotten. They have replaced your identity with a globalist fantasy, and you applaud them for it.”

The images grew more aggressive. A close-up of crumbling plaster giving way to dust. A wrecking ball swinging in a silent, brutal arc. The symbol—the broken cross—burned onto the screen, superimposed over a time-lapse of a modern skyscraper being erected, its sterile grid eclipsing the sky. The voice rose slightly in its synthesized cadence, achieving a grotesque imitation of righteous fury. “We are the cure. The harsh medicine. We will excise the tumours. We will cauterize the wounds. The teacher who poisons the minds of your children with lies of a blended future… *Remplacé*. The architect who paves over your history… *Remplacé*. We do not destroy. We purify. And the purification has only just begun.”

A new image appeared, held for a disquieting length of time. It was a view of the city from above, at night, the lights glittering like a circuit board. Then the voice delivered its final, chilling promise. “The next sermon will be delivered where the city’s heart was first replaced, where the guts of old Paris were torn out for a monument to commerce and spectacle. Seek us there.” The screen flashed to a single, stark frame of the blood-spattered blackboard from Karim Al-Jamil’s classroom, then cut to absolute black.

The silence that followed was heavier and more absolute than before, a vacuum that sucked all the air from the room. It was Dubois who broke it, slamming his fist on the heavy briefing table. The sharp crack made half the room jump. “Trace it! Now!” he roared at the terrified-looking tech analyst. “The IP address, the server logs, the account, the software used for the voice—I want everything! I want to know what this bastard had for breakfast!” His rage was a blunt instrument, a desperate attempt to impose order on a reality that had just been so thoroughly violated. It was the only tool he had left against an enemy who communicated through manifestos and severed heads.

Reiss, by contrast, seemed to shrink into herself, her focus narrowing to a single point as the room erupted into a controlled chaos of barked orders and ringing phones. She replayed the words in her head. *Hollow men. Sickness. Cure. Purify.* It was the language of a zealot, but also of a profound narcissist. The killer used ‘we’, but it was a lie. The grandeur of the tone, the bespoke symbol, the singular, theatrical vision—this was the work of one person. ‘We’ was a costume, a royal affectation worn to make a lonely, bitter pathology feel like a grand crusade. This wasn't a movement. It was a one-man show.

An hour later, after the room had mostly emptied into a city-wide flurry of frantic activity, Dubois found her still staring at the blank digital whiteboard where the video had played. The initial explosion of his anger had burned out, leaving behind the exhausted, grim-faced detective he always was. “Where the city’s heart was first replaced,” he muttered, running a hand through his thinning grey hair. “Les Halles. He’s talking about the old market. They tore it all down in the seventies for the Forum des Halles. A shopping centre and a train station.” His voice was heavy with a weary disgust. “He’s going to hit a shopping mall. A public space, packed with people. This is an escalation, Anouk. A massive one.”

“He isn't just escalating the violence,” Reiss said, her voice low and distant, as if speaking from the bottom of her pool. “He’s escalating the performance. The classroom was intimate. The courier delivery was a private horror staged for an audience of one. Now he wants an audience of thousands. He’s not just a killer, Jean-Pierre. He’s a showman.” She finally looked at him, and for the first time that day, Dubois saw not just the cold discipline in her eyes, but a flicker of something else. A deep, chilling, and disturbingly clear understanding of the monster they were hunting. “And he’s just announced his next stage.”

Her own phone vibrated on the table, a sharp, angry buzz against the polished surface. It was the forensics lab. She put it on speaker. “Reiss.” The voice on the other end was Dr. Alarie, the chief medical examiner, a woman whose calm professionalism was legendary. Today, it was frayed at the edges. “Anouk, a word on your second victim, Jean-Luc Tissot. The one who was… delivered.” There was a pause. “The decapitation was post-mortem. The cause of death was the same as Al-Jamil. Hydraulic overpressure. We found traces of the same industrial fluid in what was left of his torso. But that’s not why I’m calling.” Dr. Alarie took a breath. “We found something inside him. Or rather, inside what was left. Something the pressure didn't destroy. A small, titanium cylinder, heat-shielded. It looks like a data capsule.”

Reiss and Dubois exchanged a look of sheer disbelief. A data capsule. Hidden inside a victim. “Have you opened it?” Reiss asked, her heart beginning its percussive, deep-water thump.

“We have,” Alarie confirmed. “It contains a single file. A list. It’s not long. Just twelve names. Karim Al-Jamil was the first name on the list. Jean-Luc Tissot was the second.”

The line went dead, but the echo of Dr. Alarie’s words remained, hanging in the sterile air of the briefing room like radioactive dust. A list. A kill list, secreted inside a victim and delivered by a ghost. It was a new dimension of calculated cruelty, a move so audacious and arrogant it defied comprehension. For a moment, neither Reiss nor Dubois moved. The quiet hum of the servers and the distant, frantic ringing of phones seemed to belong to another world. They were in the killer's world now, a place where human beings were not just targets, but vessels for messages.

Dubois was the first to react, his body coiling with a surge of furious energy. He snatched his coat from the back of a chair, his movements jerky and powerful. “Get Alarie to send that list over. Now,” he barked at a nearby officer, who scrambled to comply. “I want every name on that list found and put into protective custody within the hour. I don't care if they’re having dinner with the President, I want a uniform on their doorstep five minutes ago. Move!” His voice was a whip-crack, galvanizing the residual shock in the room into a frenzy of action. For Dubois, the list was a gift. It was a tangible, actionable piece of intelligence in a case that had so far been nothing but abstract horror. It was a chance to get ahead of the monster.

Reiss, however, felt a different, colder reality crystallize within her. She walked slowly back to the digital whiteboard, where the killer’s sigil still pulsed faintly like a dark star. Dubois saw a target list; she saw a script. Talia hadn’t made a mistake. He hadn’t accidentally left them a clue. He had deliberately armed them with the knowledge of his future crimes. He was inviting them to the show, handing them a programme, confident that they were powerless to stop the performance. He wanted the police to find these ten people. He wanted the terror to spread from the anonymous victims to the named ones, to let them live with the knowledge that they were on a list, marked for a uniquely grotesque death. He was poisoning the city with fear, one name at a time.

Moments later, the list appeared on the screen, transmitted from the forensics lab. Twelve names, typed in a simple, sans-serif font.
1.  Karim Al-Jamil. History Teacher. *[Deceased]*
2.  Jean-Luc Tissot. Urban Planner. *[Deceased]*
3.  Dr. Lena Petrova. Sociologist, Sorbonne University. Specialization: Post-colonial migration patterns.
4.  Marc Vasseur. CEO, ‘Verba Lingua’ Tech. Creator of a popular real-time translation app.
5.  Ayaan Fariq. Imam, Grand Mosque of Paris. Known for progressive, interfaith outreach.
6.  Chloé-Marie Bertrand. Artist. Her latest exhibition, ‘Visages de Paris’, featured portraits of naturalized citizens.
And so it continued. A human rights lawyer. A celebrity chef whose fusion cuisine was celebrated as the taste of modern France. A journalist who had written a book debunking the ‘Grand Remplacement’ theory. A film director. Each name was a pillar of a new, multicultural France. Each was a direct refutation of the killer’s ideology. Talia wasn’t just killing people; he was trying to assassinate a vision of the future.

The briefing room became the nerve centre of a city-wide race against time. The ten names and faces, pulled from public records and social media, now stared out from the whiteboard, a gallery of the condemned. The logistics were a nightmare. Two of the people on the list were currently out of the country. One was on a train somewhere between Lyon and Paris. Another, the artist Chloé-Marie Bertrand, wasn't answering her phone or her door. Each name was a new crisis, a new potential failure point.

Dubois was in his element, a field marshal directing his troops against a known enemy. He paced before the board, phone pressed to his ear, orchestrating the chaos. “I don’t care if she’s meditating! Break the damn door down! I want eyes on Bertrand now!” he bellowed. He was fighting the battle Talia had set for him, and he was fighting it with everything he had. But Reiss stood apart from the fray, her swimmer’s discipline giving her a stillness that was almost unnerving. She was looking at the bigger picture, at the shape of the water.

“Jean-Pierre,” she said, her voice cutting quietly through his roaring. He stopped pacing and looked at her, his face flushed with adrenaline and frustration. “He’s playing with us. He gave us ten names, but he announced one location. Les Halles.”

“It’s a misdirection,” Dubois grunted, turning his attention back to the board. “He wants us to mass our forces at the mall while he picks off one of these people in their homes.”

“No,” Reiss countered, shaking her head slowly. The certainty was back, cold and absolute. “It’s the other way around. The list is the misdirection. He wants us to scatter our resources across the entire city, protecting these ten people. He wants us running in circles, putting out fires. It thins us out. It makes his real target, the public spectacle at Les Halles, that much easier to achieve. He isn't going after another name on the list next. Not yet. He’s going for the audience.”

The implication of her words slowly sank into Dubois, cutting through his adrenaline. He stared at her, then back at the board, at the ten panicked operations currently underway, at the symbol glowing in the centre of it all. Talia hadn't given them a chance to save ten people. He had given them ten new impossible tasks, ten new ways to fail, all while he prepared his grand centrepiece. The choice was excruciating: abandon the ten known targets to fortify one location, or stretch their forces so thin they could effectively protect no one? It was a perfect trap, designed by a mind that understood the machinery of police work as well as it understood the machinery of demolition. The killer was not just a madman. He was a strategist. And he was winning.

## Chapter 3

The schism between them was a silent, crackling thing in the over-caffeinated air of the briefing room. Dubois, a man forged in the procedural fires of the Brigade Criminelle, saw the list as gospel. It was a concrete directive, a set of coordinates in a sea of madness. To ignore it was professional malpractice, a dereliction of the highest order. He had already dispatched teams to every address, his voice a gravelly litany of commands that sent detectives scattering across the city’s twenty arrondissements like scattered birds. To him, Reiss’s theory about Les Halles was a dangerous abstraction, an intuitive leap he couldn’t afford to trust when lives were explicitly on the line.

“Anouk, I hear you, but this is a list of ten breathing human beings,” he argued, his voice low and tight, keeping the conflict between them. “He put them on a list and sent it to us. It’s a direct challenge. If we shift our focus to the mall and one of these people dies in their home because we weren’t there, it’s on my head. It’s on our heads.” He gestured to the gallery of worried faces on the whiteboard. “This is the front line. Here. With them.”

“And what if they are all decoys, Jean-Pierre?” Reiss countered, her tone cool and even, a stark contrast to his barely contained agitation. “What if we save all ten of them tonight, only to wake up tomorrow to news of a massacre at Les Halles? What if he’s counting on you to be a good, procedural cop? He’s studying us as much as we are studying him. He knows our protocols. This isn’t a trap of violence; it’s a trap of procedure.” She picked up her coat, a decision solidifying in her gaze. “You protect the names. I’ll go to Les Halles. I will go and read the stage he’s setting.”

Dubois wanted to argue, to order her to stay, to work the tangible leads. But he saw the absolute, unshakable certainty in her eyes—the same look she got in the final lap of a race, when she was no longer thinking, only moving. He knew it was useless. He gave a short, sharp nod, a gesture of concession and deep unease. “Take two officers with you. And for God’s sake, Anouk, be careful. Don’t go looking for him. Just look.”

The Forum des Halles was a world away from the monastic quiet of the Piscine Pontoise. It was the city’s chaotic, beating heart, a sprawling subterranean complex of commerce and transit, crowned by the Canopée, a vast, undulating roof of glass and steel that looked like a wave of frozen gold. Rain streamed down its curved surfaces, distorting the lights and faces of the thousands of people who swirled through the plaza below. Shoppers laden with bags, commuters rushing for the RER trains, teenagers loitering in crews, tourists staring up at the futuristic architecture—it was the vibrant, messy, multicultural Paris that Talia despised, all gathered under one roof. Reiss stood at the edge of the plaza, letting the sensory overload wash over her, feeling the lie of the place. It presented itself as a bright, open, public space, but she knew it was a fortress of concrete and steel, riddled with service corridors, ventilation shafts, and maintenance tunnels—a building’s secret anatomy.

Her two uniformed escorts stayed a discreet distance behind as she began to walk the perimeter, her eyes scanning not the people, but the structure. She wasn’t looking for a man in a trench coat with a bulge under his arm. Talia was more sophisticated than that. She was looking for his sermon’s pulpit. The hydraulic cannon was an industrial tool, heavy and loud. It required power, a stable firing platform, and concealment until the last possible moment. Where would a strategist place such a weapon for maximum effect, both physically and symbolically? She imagined him here, walking this same path, seeing not a shopping centre but a canvas. He had called it the place where the city's guts were torn out. He wouldn't just attack it; he would make the building itself perform the attack.

Her mind went back to the forensics report. *Polyalkylene glycol. Phosphate esters. Hydraulic fluid.* She thought of the pressure, the sheer, unimaginable force. And then her eyes settled on the grand, modern fountains that dotted the central concourse. They were currently dormant due to the rain, their stone basins slick and dark, but she knew that on sunny days, they sent arcs of dancing water high into the air, their pumps and machinery hidden deep in the building's sub-levels. Water. Pressure. The guts of the building. A cold dread, colder than any pool water, began to seep into her bones. She turned to one of the officers. “Get me the chief of security for the complex. And I need a full set of blueprints for this entire structure. Plumbing, electrical, HVAC, everything. Tell them it’s for DI Reiss, Brigade Criminelle, and it’s not a request.”

While she waited, her phone buzzed with an update from Dubois’s command centre. They had located nine of the ten people on the list. Dr. Petrova was under guard at her Sorbonne office, furious but compliant. The tech CEO, Vasseur, was being escorted from his flight at Charles de Gaulle. The Imam was safe within the walls of the Grand Mosque, surrounded by his own community and a discreet police detail. But the artist, Chloé-Marie Bertrand, was still missing. Her apartment in Montmartre was empty. No signs of a struggle. Her phone was off. Her neighbours hadn't seen her since the previous evening. A single name, unaccounted for, was enough to keep half of Dubois’s attention locked in a state of high alert. The trap was working perfectly.

The security chief was a harried man with a paunch and a perpetually worried expression, but the authority of Reiss’s presence and the gravity of her tone brooked no argument. He led her to his office, a cramped room in the bowels of the complex, and unfurled a massive set of schematics across a table. The Forum des Halles was revealed to be a dizzying labyrinth, a multi-layered ecosystem of public space and hidden infrastructure. Reiss’s eyes, trained to follow the black line at the bottom of a pool for hours, traced the intricate web of pipes and conduits. Her finger followed the main water lines, the filtration systems, the high-pressure pumps that powered the fountains. She was a swimmer, she understood systems of flow and force. She was looking for an anomaly, a modification, a point of entry into the building’s circulatory system.

There. A secondary maintenance junction for the main plaza’s water features, located in a service corridor on sublevel two, designated M-7. It was marked for a routine pressure check, scheduled for the following week. It was perfect. Obscure, accessible with basic maintenance credentials, and directly connected to the very heart of the public space. “Take me here,” she said, her finger pressing down on the map. “Now.”

The service corridors were a different world. The cheerful noise of the mall was replaced by the low hum of electricity and the drip of unseen condensation. The air was cool and smelled of damp concrete and oil. It was the city’s underbelly, a place of pure function. The security chief led them down a stark, fluorescent-lit passage to a heavy steel door marked M-7. He unlocked it, and Reiss stepped inside. The room was a tangled knot of insulated pipes, pressure gauges, and control wheels. And in the centre of the room, she saw it. A section of the main outflow pipe, about a meter long, was a different colour from the rest, the metal newer, the welds around it thicker and uglier than the clean, industrial seams elsewhere. Attached to this new section was a heavy-duty valve assembly that was clearly not part of the original design. It was a bypass, a shunt, crudely but effectively grafted onto the building’s artery. Beneath it, on the grimy concrete floor, was a dark, greasy smear.

Reiss knelt, her heart a cold, heavy stone in her chest. She didn't need a forensics kit. She knew exactly what it was. It was the same fluid they had found at the classroom, the same fluid that had permeated the remains of Jean-Luc Tissot. Talia hadn't brought his weapon to the mall. He had built it into the mall. The fountains, symbols of life and public leisure, were now the barrel of his cannon. At the flick of a switch, from anywhere in the city, he could reroute the system, build the pressure, and unleash not water, but a high-pressure jet of hydraulic death into the crowded plaza above. He was going to turn the building’s own heart against itself. The water was a lie. It was always a lie. Reiss straightened up, a terrifying clarity in her mind. She pulled out her phone, her fingers surprisingly steady as she dialled. The showman had revealed his stage. And the curtain was about to go up.

“Jean-Pierre,” she said, her voice a flat, deadly calm that was more alarming than any scream. “Forget the list. Evacuate Les Halles. He’s wired the whole place to blow.”

The line was silent for a beat, a chasm of dead air into which Dubois’s disbelief fell and was consumed. His voice, when it returned, was a rasp of incredulity and dawning horror. “Wired to blow? Anouk, what are you talking about? That’s not his method. What did you find?” He was a man clinging to the flimsy wreckage of procedure in a tidal wave of insanity, and his questions were a desperate search for a handhold.

“It’s not a bomb, Jean-Pierre, it’s worse. It’s him,” Reiss explained, her voice a low, urgent current. “He’s tapped into the fountain system. There’s a custom-built valve assembly grafted onto the main outflow pipe in a service corridor. There are traces of the same hydraulic fluid we found at the Al-Jamil scene. He’s turned the entire water feature into a weapon. He can build up an impossible amount of pressure and release it into the plaza. It’s the classroom all over again, but the classroom is the size of a football pitch and it’s filled with people.”

Another silence stretched, this one heavier, fraught with the weight of an impossible decision. Reiss could practically hear the gears turning in her partner’s head, the calculation of risk, the screams of the potential victims on the list warring with the potential for a public massacre. ## Chapter 4

## Chapter 5

The phone in her hand was a dead weight, its pulsing green screen a malevolent cyclopean eye. Reiss didn't flinch. She stood on the edge of the deck, looking down the long, sapphire lane. It was exactly as it had always been, the water a calm, inviting blue, the tiled cross a familiar promise at the far end. But it was irrevocably changed, haunted. This was no longer a sanctuary. It was a battlefield. It was a tomb. It was the stage for a final, terrible act. She could feel the memory of Lucien’s weight, the silent, brutal struggle in the depths, the ghost of his hatred. The water was a lie. It had promised her a clean, chlorinated void, but it had become the very thing she could never wash away. For a long moment, she stood perfectly still, wondering if she could ever enter it again, if the place that had once been her only peace was now lost to her forever.

Then, she stepped onto the starting block. She did not hesitate. Her body coiled into the familiar posture of readiness, her toes gripping the edge. She took a breath. It was not a breath of meditation, but of defiance. She was not here to forget. She was here to reclaim. She dove. The water was a shock, cold and absolute, but it was not an enemy. It was just water. She broke the surface and began to swim, her arms pulling, her legs kicking, her body a familiar, powerful machine. Stroke, kick, breathe. The mantra was different now. It was no longer about escape. It was a statement of survival. Stroke: *I am here.* Kick: *I am still here.* Breathe: *I will always be here.* The water could not wash the filth away, but it could bear her up. It could hold her. She was a swimmer, carving a path not through a quiet, blue void, but through the wreckage of her own history, moving forward one powerful, relentless, and deliberate stroke at a time.

Her first lap was a fight. The water, once a frictionless medium for her meditative violence, now seemed thick with memory, clinging to her like a shroud. With every pull of her arms, she felt the phantom weight of Lucien’s body, the desperate scrabble of his fingers against her skin. With every kick, she felt the sickening grind of his dislocated thumb, the terrible, intimate act of breaking another human being. The muffled, percussive thump of her own heart was no longer a comforting rhythm; it was a timer, the echo of a dead man’s switch she had worn on her own skin. She swam through a ghost-choir of his whispered words, through the image of Karim Al-Jamil’s ruined classroom, through the silent, screaming terror in Chloé-Marie Bertrand’s eyes. This was not a cleansing. It was an exorcism by immersion, a forced march through the battlefield of her own trauma.

By the tenth lap, something shifted. The ghosts did not vanish, but they receded, their screams fading to whispers, their faces blurring into the blue depths below. They were becoming part of the water, part of the landscape of this place. Her body, acting on a wisdom deeper than thought, found its rhythm again. The burn in her muscles was real, a clean, honest pain that anchored her in the present. The rasp of her own breathing was the sound of life, a defiant noise in a place that had been consecrated to death. She was not escaping the memories. She was outlasting them. She was swimming through them and out the other side, her body a relentless engine of survival. When she finally touched the wall for the last time, her limbs trembling with an exhaustion that was both physical and spiritual, she did not feel clean. She felt emptied. And in that emptiness, there was a sliver of space to begin again.

Her return to the Quai des Orfèvres was a quiet, suffocating ordeal. The bustling headquarters, once a place of gruff camaraderie and shared purpose, now felt like a foreign country. Colleagues who would normally greet her with a sarcastic remark or a weary nod now fell silent as she passed, their gazes a mixture of awe and something that looked disturbingly like fear. They made way for her in the corridors as if she were a visiting dignitary or a ghost haunting her old office. She had become a myth, a legend whispered over stale coffee and cigarettes. The Inspector who went into the water with a monster and came out wearing his heart. The story, already embellished, had made her untouchable, isolating her more completely than any secure room ever could. She was no longer just a colleague. She was a monument to a horror they had all witnessed from a safe distance.

Dubois found her staring out the window of her small office, looking down at the grey, sluggish waters of the Seine. He didn’t knock, just entered and closed the door behind him, creating a small pocket of their old reality in the changed landscape of the new. He placed a steaming cup of coffee on her desk, the gesture so familiar it was almost painful. He didn’t sit, but leaned against the filing cabinet, his expression unreadable. For a long moment, he said nothing, simply allowing the silence to settle between them. He was studying her, trying to reconcile the woman he had known for a decade with the cold, precise weapon he had seen on the monitor, the avenging angel who had risen from the water.

Finally, he spoke, his voice lower than usual, stripped of its usual bluster. “The Prefect wants to give you a commendation. The Médaille d’honneur. They’re talking about a promotion, a desk job. Head of a new task force. Anything you want, Anouk. You can write your own ticket.” He was offering her a way out, an honorable discharge from the front lines, a quiet, administrative peace. It was his way of trying to put her back in a box, to protect her, to undo what had been done. He was offering her a different kind of sanctuary.

Anouk turned from the window, a small, wry smile touching her lips. It didn't quite reach her eyes. “And spend the rest of my life shuffling papers, Jean-Pierre? Drowning in reports instead of water? No.” She picked up the coffee, the warmth of the cheap ceramic a small, grounding comfort. “I’m a homicide detective. It’s what I do. It’s who I am.” Dubois held her gaze, and in it, he saw no trace of the broken, traumatized victim he had feared he would find. He saw a scar, deep and permanent, but he also saw the familiar, unyielding iron that had always been there, now tempered into something even stronger. The fear in his eyes was replaced by a slow, dawning understanding, a profound and weary respect. He gave a single, short nod. The offer was withdrawn. The old world, or something like it, clicked back into place.

Her phone rang, the sound sharp and mundane in the quiet office. It was the central dispatch. Anouk answered, her voice its usual flat, professional tone. “Reiss.” She listened for a moment, her expression unchanging. “Alright. On our way.” She hung up and reached for her coat. Dubois raised an eyebrow, a silent question. “A body,” she said, her voice matter-of-fact. “An accountant found in his apartment in the 13th. Looks like a robbery gone wrong. Pathetic and messy.” She shrugged into her coat, the familiar weight settling on her shoulders. For the first time in days, it felt right. She was no longer a victim, a target, or a myth. She was a cop going to a crime scene. As they walked out of the office and back into the loud, chaotic hum of the Brigade Criminelle, she glanced down at her wrist. The bruised mark was still there, a faint, purple ghost beneath her watch. It was a part of her now, a map of where she had been. But it was not a chain. It was just a scar. The city was still filled with filth, with pathetic, messy, sordid tragedies. The water was still a lie. But she no longer needed it to be true. She walked out of the building and into the grey Parisian drizzle, a detective heading back to work, her eyes clear and focused on the unyielding, un-washable truth of the world she had chosen.
